I have never said that the Affordable Care Act is a perfect law. While the bill was being drafted, I fought for the creation of national exchanges and a national not-for profit plan that I hoped would set the example for single-payer healthcare. I also advocated for other critical reforms, including eliminating the anti-trust immunity for the insurance industry and regulating pharmaceutical pricing.  Unfortunately, Republicans in the Senate blocked these improvements to the legislation, and in the next election, they took over the House. Since that time the Republicans have done nothing but vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act; in six years they have never offered a plan to replace or improve the existing system.  I think there is broad agreement that the law needs improvement to benefit more Americans. However, the path to meaningful improvement is through bipartisan compromise—not through a reckless, partisan process rushed by Republican leadership to dismantle the Affordable Care Act with zero proposals to replace it. This approach will ruthlessly strip healthcare coverage from more than 30 million Americans, including more than 475,000 Oregonians.  Before congressional Republicans take the Affordable Care Act to the chopping block, they need to remember the reasons we passed healthcare reform in the first place. Eight years ago, insurance companies had free reign to price-gouge consumers. Individuals with pre-existing conditions could be denied healthcare coverage. Insurance companies could refuse to renew your coverage policy if you got sick. Costs were skyrocketing and the consumer—not big insurance companies—were paying the price. The Affordable Care Act changed all that and provided protection and security to millions of Americans. Today, our nation’s uninsured rate is the lowest it has ever been.  If the Affordable Care Act were to be repealed immediately, we would lose those protections. More than half a million Oregonians included under the law’s Medicaid expansion would lose coverage, and Oregon would be at risk to lose $3.56 billion in federal Medicaid dollars. Approximately 28,000 young people who have been allowed to stay on their parents’ insurance plans until age 26 could lose their insurance. More than 50,000 children across our state who benefit from the Children’s Health Insurance Program would be at risk of having their health insurance rolled back. Insurance companies would no longer be required to provide free preventative care. Oregon seniors will be forced to pay more for prescription drugs.  The law needs improvement, but we cannot overlook the enormous benefits that the Affordable Care Act has provided tens of millions of Americans and hundreds of thousands of Oregonians. Improvements should be made in a deliberative and cooperative way. I urge my Republican colleagues not to rush the process to gain political points at the expense of families who depend on the Affordable Care Act.

I feel that my time this week will be best spent at home in Oregon rather than attending the inauguration festivities. In the next few days, I will be in my community, meeting with my constituents and discussing their priorities for the year. I usually do not attend presidential inauguration ceremonies and do my best to avoid pomp and circumstance events in Washington, and this year will be no different.   In the 115th Congress, I will be prepared to work with President-elect Trump where we find common ground, but I also will not hesitate to fight back against the President-elect when necessary.
There's a lot on the agenda for the 115th Congress. I recorded a message about my priorities for the year ahead:

If the Affordable Care Act is repealed, we need to make sure consumers are protected from health insurance companies price gouging. My bill would ensure that health insurance companies are subject to the same anti-trust laws as everybody else (except Major League Baseball).

This weekend, President Trump issued an ill-conceived and unlawful executive order that grossly missed its mark in an apparent attempt to strengthen our national security. Instead, it sends a message that Muslims are not welcome in America, alienates our allies and serves as a recruiting tool for ISIS and other terrorists groups, ultimately making America less secure.   The executive order uses false rhetoric and preys upon Americans' fears without doing anything to address the real terrorist threats facing our nation. Instead, it resulted in the detention of a 77-year-old grandmother planning to visit her family in Texas, an Iraqi translator who risked his life to work for the U.S. Army and two doctors working at the Cleveland Clinic, just to name a few.   The current refugee vetting process is already one of the most thorough screening processes for foreign visitors. This executive order does nothing to strengthen America’s national security, and instead has given the U.S. a black eye in the international community.   The worst terrorist attack on our nation, 9/11, was carried out by radicals from Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Lebanon and the UAE. The attacks in San Bernardino were carried out by a Pakistani terrorist and an American-born terrorist. None of the procedures put in place by this executive order would have prevented any of these attacks.  This irresponsible order puts our nation at risk and stands in opposition to the ideals that our country was founded upon. It’s clear to me that my colleagues in Congress on both sides of the aisle will need to work together to restrain President Trump from inflicting more damage to our country.   I am joining my colleagues today to introduce the “Statue of Liberty Values Act” (SOLVe) which nullifies the executive order. The legislation states that it will have no effect or force of law and states that no funds or fees shall be used to implement the order.
Today I went to the House Floor and demanded a vote to repeal President Trump's Executive Order. We need to put american values first.

We need an Education Secretary with real experience who will improve our public schools, not starve them. Our kids deserve better. #DumpDevos

Today, millionaires stop paying into Social Security for the rest of 2017. I'm introducing legislation with U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders to close this loophole and strengthen Social Security for future generations. http://bit.ly/2kDo0Ye

I'm proud that my legislation, the Social Security Expansion Act, was endorsed by the National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare. People have paid into Social Security for their entire working lives—Congress must ensure the program's solvency for today's beneficiaries and future generations.

Next week, President Trump will give his first address to a Joint Session of Congress. I anticipate that among many things, he will discuss the Affordable Care Act and his plans to repeal it.  In advance of this speech, I want to hear from my constituents about how repealing the Affordable Care Act would impact them and their families. While I have never said that the Affordable Care Act was a perfect law, the help it has given hundreds of thousands of Oregonians is undeniable.   Since 2013, the rate of uninsured people in Oregon's 4th district has dropped by 9 percent. The expansion of Medicaid resulted in $680.8 million federal dollars directed to our community. Across the country, millions of families are being helped every single day. The consequences of repealing the Affordable Care Act—especially without a concrete plan to replace it—would be catastrophic.  I am collecting the stories of people in my district who have been helped by the Affordable Care Act in order to put a human face on the debate in Washington. If you or a family member would be impacted by the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, please leave your story below in the comments.

Tomorrow night, President Trump will give his first joint address to Congress and lay out his legislative priorities for the year—including the repeal of the Affordable Care Act. Traditionally, each member of Congress is given a ticket for one guest to watch the President’s speech from the House Gallery. I’ve brought a number of well-deserving Oregonians in years past. Last year, I brought Steve Phillips, an out-of-work paper mill employee who had lost three jobs thanks to unfair foreign competition and our failed trade policies. Steve demonstrated the terrible impact that a new proposed trade deal, the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP), would have had on our manufacturing economy—a deal we killed last fall.  This year I’m doing something different: I will be leaving my guest’s seat empty to represent one of my constituents who will go bankrupt, or die, if the Affordable Care Act is repealed. Across the country, people are pushing back against the threat of repeal with a massive outpouring of support for the ACA. If we continue to make our voices heard, we can defeat efforts to repeal this landmark legislation and perhaps make long overdue improvements.  In addition, this week I will be sharing stories from constituents who have been impacted by the ACA. Last week, I asked how the ACA has helped you and your family, and since then I’ve heard from scores of constituents. From reading your comments, it’s clear to me that we simply cannot go back to the ‘good old days’ of health insurance, when consumers were price-gouged, sick people were kicked off their coverage, and individuals were unable to get any insurance due to pre-existing conditions. We can, and must, do better, for all those who stand to lose their healthcare if the ACA is repealed.

This week, I will be highlighting constituent stories from Oregonians who have been impacted by the Affordable Care Act.   For my first ACA story, Susan from Springfield writes:   In 2008, I experienced a major medical issue involving my heart.  I was uninsured, hospitalized and in the intensive care unit. I was given a diagnosis of heart failure without a known cause.  I was now uninsurable because of a “pre-existing condition”. The cost for one night in intensive care (and there were many) was $27,000—not including medication, tests, or cardiac specialists.     I lost my ability to work at all. I could no longer afford to see any doctor other than at the local county medical clinic. They could not properly treat me because I could not afford the additional testing required to rule out, or confirm a diagnosis, nor see a specialist that could. I was prescribed medications that I could not afford, and began experiencing very serious side effects to the medications.    I sold my house during the “housing crash” to pay my medical bills. Within a short period of time, I was broke, unable to work, and now homeless. I cannot begin to express not only the fear, shame, and absolute humility I felt not being able to take care of myself-  having to rely on others for a roof over my head, but even more so, my inability to help my children during such a critical time in their lives. I could not afford to get the mental health support I needed during these times. I was told I was dying and that I needed to get my affairs in order.    When the Affordable Care Act became law, I was able to get insurance, and was able to see the specialists I needed. I was told that I have three to five years to live from the date of my original diagnosis.  That was 2008.  It is now 2017. If I had not received the insurance that I did, I would not have received the care that I did, and I would have died.

Cherry, from Albany:  Prior to my husband’s death in 2012, we both had health care through his employer. When my husband passed away I was offered the choice of staying on that same plan through COBRA—at the cost of almost $700 a month. I could not afford this.  Instead, the only insurance that I could afford was catastrophic health insurance, which allowed me to go to the doctor with a co-pay of $30 four times a year, or a specialist with a co-pay of $50 four times a year. If I needed to see either after this, my insurance covered nothing until I paid the $11,000 deductible. To have this insurance, I was paying over $300 a month.  After the Affordable Care Act passed, I was finally able to afford healthcare that covered all my medical care. It is my fear that if the Affordable Health Care is repealed, I and millions of others will not be able to afford health care that covers our needs. It feels as if we are losing so much as it is.  Check out more stories on my website: http://defazio.house.gov/the-affordable-care-act-stories-from-oregon

Peter, from Eugene:  Several years ago I had the great pleasure of retiring at the age of  60.. And then….. at 62 I was diagnosed with prostate cancer. I was devastated, but with radical prostatectomy surgery I am now cancer free. But the surgery was expensive. I very quickly hit the out of pocket limits of my insurance plan but not having insurance would have been financial overwhelming.  Without the ACA I’m not sure if I would have had insurance. Without insurance I’m not sure my cancer would have been caught and treated so early. I feel like I owe my life to the ACA, if not my life, then at least a big chunk of my retirement savings.

Stacey, from Roseburg:  I am a nurse and small business owner in Roseburg, OR. In 2007 I lost my healthcare through divorce and was not eligible for coverage through my employer because I was self-employed full-time and only worked part-time at the local hospital. Both my son and I were declined healthcare when I applied for coverage due to pre-existing conditions: My son had had bronchitis in the last two years, and I had osteoporosis. We were otherwise healthy, non-smokers.  Today, I still do not have employer-based health insurance but have purchased it through the exchange for my husband and myself. We do not qualify for any assistance and the premiums are high but I am very grateful for our plan and our pre-tax HSA contributions over the past four years.  I do not have a dramatic story. This is a story that many of us share and there are MANY stories that are dramatic with lives being saved by the ACA throughout our country. Please do not allow the ACA to be repealed.

The GOP's so-called healthcare plan would  leave 24 million Americans without health insurance and give massive tax breaks to the wealthiest.

Earlier this month, I asked to you to share how the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has helped you and your family. Since then, I've heard from dozens of my constituents who would become bankrupt, gravely ill, or in some cases, even die without the ACA and the affordable healthcare coverage it provides.  This week, House Republicans are planning to repeal the ACA and instead enact a plan that would gut Medicaid and strip coverage from 24 million Americans while handing a huge tax cut to millionaires.   I will continue to post stories about how my constituents have been impacted by the Affordable Care Act. Now more than ever, we must push back against efforts to repeal this landmark legislation and show our support for the ACA.

Jay, from Eugene:  “In 2015 I was diagnosed with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia and shortly thereafter I was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer as well.  I was given a life expectancy of only 2 – 3 years with treatment and was told that without treatment, I would die within three months. With treatment, I only had a 50% chance of going into remission.   “For the past two years, I have been on and off chemotherapy treatments. The costs of these treatments left me barely able to avoid bankruptcy, and in February 2016 my home was nearly foreclosed on. It was incredibly stressful to live in fear of foreclosure while going through chemotherapy."   “The only way that I could get access to this care—in fact, the only way that I was able to go to the doctor to receive my diagnosis—was through the Affordable Care Act. I read that former South Carolina Senator Jim DeMint called Obamacare “a cancer on our healthcare system.”  He wouldn’t say that to my face. It saved my life.   “Thankfully, my home was saved with the help of my brother and the Home Affordable Refinance Program. Today, I am healthier and am trying to pay it forward as an advocate for the Affordable Care Act: if President Trump and Congressional Republicans take our insurance, thousands of people will die. I’m proof of that.”  "It's important that everyone understands they we are fathers, mothers, grandparents, brothers, sisters and friends.  Not just statistics."

Bashar al-Assad is a brutal dictator whose inhumane chemical attacks against his own people are an unspeakable atrocity.  However, President Trump’s actions last night in attacking a Syrian airfield constitute a military action taken without congressional authorization. I have repeatedly called on President Trump to respect Congress’s war-making powers and consult with Congress before committing U.S. troops to any military conflict, as laid out in Article I of the Constitution and the War Powers Resolution. We cannot allow ourselves to be led into another open-ended conflict in the Middle East without clear objectives and an exit strategy. I urge President Trump to immediately consult Congress on his plans for the campaign in Syria, seek congressional authorization under the War Powers Resolution before any further engagement, and let the American people know our exit strategy.
Next week I will be holding town hall meetings across SW Oregon. Check the schedule to see when I'll be near you!

Finished up a great trip thru SW Oregon today: 5 town halls, 2 days, enthusiastic and engaged crowds of constituents including seniors, students and veterans. Topics ranged from how I’m working to finance repairs to our nation’s crumbling infrastructure to Medicare and the Affordable Care Act to President Trump’s agenda. Looking forward to more later this year!
Nearly 100 days in & DC is swampier than ever. I have a bill to help Pres Trump keep his promise to #DraintheSwamp:

The first version of #Trumpcare wasn't bad enough, so right-wing Republicans made it even worse. This bill strips individuals with pre-existing conditions of affordable healthcare coverage, and allows insurance companies to charge older Americans as much as they want for coverage. President Trump and Congressional Republicans promised to protect individuals with pre-existing conditions--this new bill shows that those promises were nothing but lies.

The firing of FBI Director James Comey is a disturbing development in the Trump administration’s continued systematic obstruction of the investigation into Russian interference in our presidential election. We are still learning the troubling details surrounding Director Comey’s dismissal, including the fact that Attorney General Sessions—who, after multiple major revelations and embarrassments for the administration, recused himself from the Russia investigation due to his involvement in the Trump campaign—was directly involved with the decision to fire the FBI Director.  I have believed for some time that the only way to uncover the truth about the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia is to appoint a truly independent special prosecutor to conduct a thorough, unbiased investigation into the matter, and this latest incident only strengthens that belief. I have co-sponsored legislation to create an independent commission devoted to this investigation, and I urge Republican leadership to put aside any partisan differences and immediately act to look into this matter.

Today, the Trump Administration formally notified Congress that they intend to renegotiate the North American Free Trade agreement (NAFTA). I have been fighting against NAFTA for nearly 25 years and will push the Administraion to ensure any new agreement works for all Americans and brings jobs back to the U.S.

The White House is lauding this budget as ‘Taxpayers First’, when in reality that could not be further from the truth. This budget puts giant corporations, millionaires and billionaires, and defense contractors first, and the everyday Americans last.   The President’s budget guts funding for critical programs that working families rely on and instead spends $1.6 billion on a completely useless wall between the U.S. and Mexico.  It gives an additional $52 billion to our already bloated Pentagon, while slashing $143 billion from federal student loan programs and completely eliminating funding for before-and-after-school programs, affecting an estimated 10,700 Oregon students. The President’s budget ends public service loan forgiveness and gets rid of subsidized loans for all students, while failing to adjust Pell Grants for inflation—for the first time in six years.  It strips $48 billion from Social Security’s disability program (an earned benefit), fails to deliver on promised infrastructure investment, makes cruel cuts to Meals on Wheels, and cuts federal funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), also known as food stamps, by 25%.    The budget cuts funding for programs like Foster Grandparents, Senior Companions, AmeriCorps and YouthBuild that benefit thousands of Oregonians and the individuals and communities they serve, while irresponsibly ballooning the deficit.   This is not a budget that reflects the priorities of the American people. Instead, the candidate who campaigned on behalf of working Americans has created a budget that prioritizes only the very wealthiest.
Great visit with SCORE today at the University of Oregon talking about the importance of #STEM education.

I had a great time at the Eugene Delta Rotary this afternoon speaking about common sense solutions for making critical investments in our country's crumbling infrastructure. I was also inspired to hear from a number of Rotary Foundation Scholarship winners who plan to enroll in the University of Oregon, Oregon State University, Lane Community College, and Northwest Christian University in the fall!   In addition, I'm honored that the Delta Rotary sponsored 100 vaccinations through the Rotary Global Polio Eradication effort on my behalf. Thanks to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation's 3-1 match, this will result in the equivalent of 400 Polio vaccinations. Thank you to the Delta Rotary for hosting me today and for all the work you do for our community and the world.

Today, I will be standing with the Mansfield family of Pocatello, Idaho, calling on Congress to pass my bill banning the use of lethal devices and poisons like Compound 1080 and the chemicals used in M-44 cyanide bombs. Earlier this year, the Mansfield family lost their beloved dog and nearly lost their 14 year-old son after they accidentally detonated an M-44 device planted on public land.   The Mansfields are not the only family that has experienced this tragedy: The use of these deadly toxins by Wildlife Services for so-called ‘predator control’ has caused the deaths of countless innocent family pets and devastating injuries to humans. The USDA must end the use of these cruel and dangerous poisons before more innocent people and animals are hurt.   You can watch this press conference LIVE on my Facebook page today at 2pm EST.

Today, I am standing with the Mansfield family of Pocatello, Idaho, calling on Congress to pass my bill banning the use of lethal devices and poisons like Compound 1080 and the chemicals used in M-44 cyanide bombs. Earlier this year, the Mansfield family lost their beloved dog and nearly lost their 14 year-old son after they accidentally detonated an M-44 device planted on public land.   The Mansfields are not the only family that has experienced this tragedy: The use of these deadly toxins by Wildlife Services for so-called ‘predator control’ has caused the deaths of countless innocent family pets and devastating injuries to humans. The USDA must end the use of these cruel and dangerous poisons before more innocent people and animals are hurt.

The ‘Wrong Choice’ Act would take us back to the bad old days—the days of the collapse of Wall Street, when bad mortgages, collateralized debt obligations and other schemes brought about the worst economic collapse in this country since the Great Depression. To this day, no Wall Street executive has seen jail time for the national catastrophe they created.   Now that Goldman Sachs executives hold top positions at the White House and the Treasury Department, they want to deregulate Wall Street again. This legislation gets rid of much-needed watchdogs in our financial sector and puts corporate executives, not working Americans, first.

After Director Comey’s candid and enlightening testimony, my concerns about the Trump Administration’s continued systemic obstruction of the investigation into Russian interference in our presidential election have only deepened further. Today, the American people were given strong evidence of our President’s apparent interference in an ongoing FBI investigation.    From the beginning, I have called for an independent prosecutor as well as a bipartisan, independent commission  to investigate these issues. Director Comey’s testimony only highlighted the need to allow former FBI Director Mueller to complete the investigation free from undue influence, especially from the commander-in-chief.
My thoughts are with those affected by this morning's shooting. Grateful for the Capitol Police, who put their lives on the line every day.

I’m frustrated by a missed opportunity today to do something about long security screening lines and congestion at TSA checkpoints.  My bill, the FASTER Act, was defeated in today’s Homeland Security Committee markup session. My proposal, which was considered as an amendment to the Department of Homeland Security Authorization Act, would ease congestion and delays at TSA airport checkpoints by ensuring that passenger security fees are directed toward security needs and cannot be raided by the government for other unrelated uses. These funds already exist—they are levied on the consumer when they buy their airline ticket—but Congressional Republicans continue to raid the fund for other uses.   TSA needs to address ongoing threats to airline safety. The funds to do so are available but TSA continues to lack the resources it desperately needs and travelers expect in order to mask ballooning federal deficits through a budget gimmick.   Although my legislation was a commonsense solution to a problem affecting millions of Americans, it was voted down along party lines in today’s committee markup. I will continue to fight to ensure that revenues collected from passengers are used to help finance the costs of aviation security screening, as Congress initially intended.

After weeks writing a bill in secret, Senate Republicans today released their changes to the American Health Care Act. Unfortunately, this bill really isn't that different from the House version of the bill, which would strip healthcare from 23 million Americans and dramatically increase costs for seniors.   Although there hasn't been a single hearing, mark-up, or a chance for public input on this bill, the Senate will vote on it in a few days.   Republicans say that this legislation is about improving the ACA. If it was, I'd support it, as I have always believed that the Affordable Care Act needs significant changes. Instead, this bill is about one thing and one thing only: tax cuts for the wealthy. This bill gives massive tax breaks to individuals earning more than $200,000 a year, and those earning more than $1 million a year will receive more than $50,000 in tax cuts.  Republicans in the House and Senate are delivering tax cuts to America's millionaires and billionaires under the guise of reforming healthcare. Don't let them fool you.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VJeSkE9Nrqc
NA

It's hot in Washington, but things are even hotter in the Senate. Senate Republicans’ newest version of the Healthcare reform bill is in many ways worse than before. This latest bill would allow insurance companies to sell what I like to call 'fake insurance'—plans that wouldn't be required to cover in-patient, out-patient, preventative, or emergency medical care. It's time for Republicans to come to the table and talk about meaningful bipartisan reform that will provide more people better, more affordable care.  http://bit.ly/2u2pX8c

Today, the House Budget Committee is marking up the GOP’s FY 2018 budget. Our national debt has ballooned to nearly twenty trillion dollars, yet the GOP’s highest priority is tax cuts for our nation’s wealthiest. It’s impossible to balance the budget with a massive increase in defense spending and massive tax cuts for the wealthy—that is, without slashing funding from programs that working Americans depend upon. Under the GOP’s budget, student loans, school lunch programs, food stamps, and earned benefits like Medicare are all on the chopping block. My legislation would balance the budget through prudent reductions in spending while protecting the programs Americans rely on.

Today I joined the workers at Johnson Crushers International in Eugene and discussed the need for increased investment in infrastructure nationwide.

Every year I hold dozens of Town Hall Meetings across SW Oregon to hear from my constituents and fill them in about what I’m working on in Washington. Tonight I am in Eugene at Churchill High School, ready to talk to Oregonians and answer their questions. Watch the Town Hall Meeting here!

I had a great time visiting Rescue Express in Lane County this morning. This Eugene organization rescues dogs and cats from high-kill shelters in California and transports them to rescue groups and no-kill shelters throughout the Pacific Northwest. Since 2015, Rescue Express has saved more than 10,000 animals. I'm proud such an amazing organization is right here in Eugene!

I condemn the brutal attack in Charlottesville -- which resulted in the tragic deaths of a peaceful protester and two law enforcement officers--in the strongest possible terms.  Thousands of brave men and women served and died in World War II to keep the world free from Nazism and its perverse ideals, and the bigotry and hatred they fought against has no place in America today. It should not have taken the President 48 hours to name these groups for what they are: Anti-Americans, Neo-Nazi fascists, and domestic terrorists.
I will be on the coast next week, holding Town Hall Meetings in Coos Bay, Bandon and Florence. I hope you can join me!

My staff and I have been closely monitoring the Chetco Bar fire in the Brookings area and we are keeping in close touch with incident command and federal authorities to ensure that crews have every available resource to fight this blaze. I'm grateful to the firefighters, first responders, and all of those who are battling the fires on the front lines.
I'll be holding Town Hall Meetings tomorrow in Bandon and Coos Bay - hope to see you there!
I toured the Coos Bay U.S. Coast Guard station earlier today and saw their lifesaving boats - including one that was heading out on a rescue mission!
Previewed the new Lane Transit District West Eugene EmX Bus Rapid Transit service yesterday. Will give riders more options & faster rides.

President Trump’s decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program is both cruel and unnecessary. It is my sincere belief that individuals who were brought illegally into this country as infants or young children, through no choice of their own, should not be targeted for deportation.    Our immigration system is broken. But rather than targeting nearly a million vulnerable, law-abiding youth who have built their lives in the U.S., Congress needs to work towards comprehensive immigration reform.    Congress should pass H.R. 496, the BRIDGE ACT. Like DACA, this legislation affords temporary relief for law abiding youth to continue their education or work legally until such a time as Congress passes comprehensive immigration reforms.

This past weekend I visited the Eagle Creek and Chetco Bar fires with US Forest Service Chief Tooke. Not only I was able to see up close the devastation these massive fires have caused, but I was able to meet with and personally thank the hundreds of firefighters battling these blazes. I'm proud I was able to secure additional funds to help manage these fires.

I'm proud to announce a $1 million grant from U.S. Department of Transportation has been awarded to Oregon to help repair roads and highways damaged by wildfire.These fires have decimated over 600,000 acres of land in Oregon, including roads and highways, and have impeded commerce and Oregonians' ability to move around the state. This grant will help us begin to repair the damage from these massive fires.  http://bit.ly/2frERNP

Republicans are giving zombies a bad name with their latest efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act - the bill just won't die. It was bad enough when Republicans tried to pass a bill that would strip healthcare from 23 million Americans. Now the Senate is pushing a new bill-without any analysis by the Congressional Budget Office-that would allow insurance companies to discriminate against seniors and those with pre-existing conditions, include lifetime caps, and take away the required coverage for essential benefits like prescription drug coverage or emergency room visits. This bill would be disastrous for millions of Americans and I stand firmly against it.

President Trump and congressional Republicans have abandoned their plans to overturn the Affordable Care Act—for the moment. Now, they're proposing a tax reform package that they promise will benefit the middle class, but will in reality give a huge windfall to the very wealthiest Americans. President Trump says that this package won't help him, but there's no way for us to know that—he still hasn't released his tax returns.  This plan will drive up our national debt by more than $2 TRILLION, creating a huge increase in interest rates and further hurting working Americans. We haven't seen much so far, but what we've seen is truly loathsome.

Mexican truckers are not held to the U.S.’s stringent safety standards, including drug and alcohol testing and hours of service limits, yet they’re allowed to drive on our roads. We must fix the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)  and stop trading away our highway safety.

Today I stood with former Representative Gabby Giffords and Representative John Lewis calling for the following actions in the wake of the Las Vegas shooting:  1)      Republicans withdraw their proposed Sportsmen’s Package, also known as the SHARE Act, which I have already announced my opposition to;  2)      Speaker Ryan name a Select Committee to investigate the causes of and lessen the potential for gun violence in America, and;  3)      Bring up for a vote comprehensive background check legislation that includes closing the gun show loophole and the individual internet sale loophole.  Furthermore, it is clear that the use of a bump-stock played a terrible role in the tragedy in Las Vegas. Anything that converts a semi-automatic weapon into a near-fully automatic weapon should not be sold in the United States.

I was shocked to read Senator Bob Corker’s comments about his fear that President Trump is putting our nation on the path to World War III. Under the Constitution, only Congress has the power to declare war, and it is imperative that we reassert that authority, especially in a climate where President Trump is inclined to escalate hostilities through Twitter. My resolution, H.J. Res 75, would clarify Congress’s war-making authority and require the President to come to Congress and ask for a declaration of war before committing troops into conflict.

President Trump’s announcement today on the Iran nuclear deal amounts to playing with fire. His decision to decertify Iran’s compliance with the Iran nuclear agreement and potentially terminate the deal if his administration cannot reach a new agreement with Congress and our allies is short-sighted and dangerous. It could ultimately further destabilize the Middle East and allow Iran to resume their pursuit of developing nuclear weapons.    The current nuclear agreement imposes strict limits and a robust transparency requirement on Iran's nuclear program, and drastically increases the time it would take for Iran to build a nuclear bomb. Our allies and experts around the globe, including those in President Trump’s Administration, agree the agreement is working. President Trump and Congress must ensure that the U.S. remains a part of this critical agreement to keep Iran from ever developing a nuclear weapon and ultimately foster a permanent peaceful resolution to this matter.

For the last seven years, all we've heard from the GOP about the Affordable Care Act has been "Repeal and Replace." Now, President Trump has moved on to "Destroy and Smirk." Yesterday he took away premium support for thousands of low-income families and shortsightedly allowed plans to be sold across state lines with no regulation--something Congress banned 25 years ago. If President Trump actually has a plan to fix American healthcare, I'd love to see it. In the meantime, he seems intent upon unraveling much-needed protections for thousands of American families while ignoring the terrible damage he is inflicting upon the health insurance marketplace.

Poor management has created a toxic culture at the Eugene and Roseburg VA facilities, leading to substandard veteran patient care and chasing away good medical providers. I’m calling on the VA to finally take appropriate action to ensure that Oregon’s veterans receive the care that they deserve.

I held a productive roundtable discussion with community college students and financial aid directors this afternoon on ways to make education more affordable and attainable for all.   Community college students often have different needs than students at a traditional four-year institution—they are often older, returning to school to start a new career, single parents finishing their schooling, or professionals balancing their jobs and their education. In Washington, there is a dearth of legislation that addresses these needs, and it is my hope that I can take what I learned today back to DC to change that.

Investigators from the VA's Office of the Medical Inspector will be visiting both the Roseburg and the Eugene VA facilities next week. The investigators will be in Oregon to speak with VA staff objectively about issues affecting personnel and patient care.   The Congressman has been assured that any retaliation against those who speak to the investigators will not be tolerated.  For those who are still concerned about potential retaliation, our office can facilitate confidential conversations to protect your identity. Please call (541) 465-6732 for assistance.
Today is the first day of the Open Enrollment period. Visit healthcare.gov and #GetCovered!
The Republican's tax plan is a turkey, and it ought to die before Thanksgiving.
Republicans say that their tax plan will help the middle class -- nothing could be further from the truth.

This past weekend I was part of a congressional delegation that traveled to Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands to see the damage inflicted by Hurricanes Maria and Irma.  I saw extraordinary devastation everywhere I went. It is clear that a massive federal effort is needed, and the recovery will take years, not months, to complete. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) needs major reform in order to provide the flexibility these islands need in order to rebuild in order to do resilient reconstruction, given the growing intensity of hurricanes and tropical storms due to climate change. Transportation and Infrastructure Committee Chairman Bill Shuster and I have agreed to make those reforms a priority.
NA

After committee markup of the GOP tax plan, the bill is still a massive tax break for the wealthy paid for by raising taxes on the middle class and exploding our national debt, leaving the next generation to pay the bill. #GOPTaxScam

Today House Republicans pushed through their massive tax plan that will likely put America on the road to bankruptcy and will add $2 trillion to our nation's debt. The American people need to hold the GOP accountable for this outrageous bill.
Open Enrollment for 2018 ends December 15. Don’t miss out on affordable plans. Go to healthcare.gov and #GetCoveredNow!

North Korea has launched another missile, and all President Trump can do is continue to escalate tensions. His recklessness could drive our country into a nuclear war of global proportions, which is why I've introduced a bill to reassert that Congress, not the President, holds the constitutional authority to declare war: https://youtu.be/atWKGBcqyJ0

We’re witnessing a much-needed sea change in society in which sexual harassment and abuse of power is no longer tolerated. While today’s vote is a step in the right direction, we have a lot more work to do. It’s clear that the House of Representatives' process for reporting and adjudicating claims of sexual harassment needs substantial reform, especially with regards to accountability and transparency.   I’m proud to have a zero-tolerance policy in my office for sexual harassment of any kind, and Congress as a whole should meet that high standard.
Today I'm sitting down with my fellow Oregon representatives - Suzanne Bonamici (OR-1), Earl Blumenauer (OR-03), and Kurt Schrader (OR-5) to talk about the #GOPTaxScam and its impact on Oregonians.
Today I called on FCC Chairman Ajit Pai to protect #NetNeutrality. We must ensure that the internet remains a free and open space for everyone -- not just big corporations.
NA
The #GOPTaxScam is a Christmas present to America's wealthiest, and a lump of coal to working families.

My thoughts are with the loved ones of the victims and all those injured in the terrible Amtrak train crash in Washington this morning. We don’t yet know the cause of the horrific derailment which took the lives of multiple people, and we need to let the NTSB conduct a thorough investigation into the cause of the accident. As Ranking Member of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure I will continue to monitor the situation, and work together with my colleagues to enact any changes necessary to prevent this type of accident in the future once we have more information about the cause.

Apparently the first time wasn't bad enough. We just heard that the just-passed #GOPTaxScam violates Senate rules. It has to be changed and come back to the House AGAIN for another vote tomorrow. Shows how hastily this shoddy bill was thrown together by Republicans.

It's a dark day: the House just passed a massive tax bill that gives trillions in giveaways to corporations and the wealthiest Americans. This is just another example of shameful 'trickle-on' economics, and working Americans deserve better.

While we've been waiting for President Trump's trillion dollar infrastructure investment, the GOP has designed a tax bill that gives trillions of dollars to our nation's very wealthiest. If we invested that same money in infrastructure, we could create millions of family-wage jobs and finally repair and improve our nation's crumbling infrastructure. The #GOPTaxScam shows just how misguided the GOP's priorities truly are.

I’m proud that after many years, Congress has finally passed my bill, the Western Oregon Tribal Fairness Act, and it will now head to the President's desk for signature. This bill will give sovereignty over tribal land back to the Coos and Cow Creek Tribes and allows the Coquille Tribe to manage their forest lands the same way as all other tribal forest lands. While there is still much work to be done to correct our nation’s injustices towards Native Americans, the passage of this legislation is an encouraging move toward progress.
Wishing everyone a happy New Year!  Im looking forward to another year representing SW Oregon.
